text: Hi everybody. Welcome to customizing
anything embracing mutable. My name is
Dustin Dvau. I'm a technical animator on
the tech devril team at Epic. And today
I want to go over a plugin that's been
in Unreal for a little while, but it
just went into beta called Mutable. and
we're going to go over what it is, some
use cases for it, as well as like I'm
going to do a hands-on demo showing you
guys how to use it. In Unreal Fest
Orlando, Gerard Martin, who's a part of
the Mutable team, did a presentation
about Mutable as well. And much to my
chagrin, there was quite a bit of
overlap. So, his presentation goes over
kind of some deep dives of how the
system works. I'm gonna show you guys
how to use it and get started because a
lot of times new studios and and upand
cominging smaller indie studios want to
use something like this but it's a
little daunting to get into.
So what is mutable? At the end of the
day mutable simply put is a tool for
customizing and merging meshes. So,
this comes with some caveats associated
with it that I'll show today, but it has
a big featurerich tool set to do this to
make efficient optimized message for
your game for a bunch of different
cases. It has a couple strengths. The
first one is that it's got async runtime
and baking features to generate these
meshes. You can use it at runtime and
load these things into memory and use
them in your gameplay. Or if you want
and you don't can't afford that, you can
still have your customization options.
Take all these meshes that you want to
combine, put them into a customizable
object and bake them out to create a
whole suite of characters for crowds or
NPCs or things like that. The other
thing that it does is that you can edit
and modify your meshes and your
textures. and I'll show that in the demo
today.
And it's got support for expanding
content. If you're working on a live
service game and you need to add content
over time, you can still add more to the
system and still create those efficient
meshes for later on in the the game's
life cycle.
So, what would you use this for? The
first thing that comes to mind is
character customization. So often times
when we're building a character
customizer, you think about it in parts
and slots and you can combine those
together to reduce the overall all
component count for your characters. On
top of that, you can take objects that
have a similar root skeleton and combine
those together. The example that I often
use is you have a character and you want
to add a backpack to them. You can do
that as long as the root chain in that
skeleton is tied together. And I'll show
that later, too.
And you can apply mesh edits like morph
targets, uh, mesh removal and
adjustment, as well as handling
overlapping meshes. So you can see here
in this image, uh, we've got a t-shirt
and I want to tuck the arm into that
t-shirt. You can modify the mesh at that
tuck point on a per object basis.
The other thing that you can do is you
can do texture and material
customization applying player chosen
textures and material edits as well as
generate atlas textures that are
efficient for the runtime. And you can
do texture projection. Think like
decals. I have a jacket. I want to put
some patches on it or I want to do
tattoos. And you can position that as a
player or you can position it ahead of
time in your customizable object graph.
The other area that you can use this is
in modular attachments and systems for
things like weapons that are more
static, but you still want to combine
parts together to create like uh guns
and that have scopes and things like
that. Just think of them like characters
and all the other systems apply.
And then lastly is vehicles is another
use case too. So similarly you can
attach things to chassis, combine those
all together, output a skeleton mesh to
use in something like KS vehicle for
example that can drive those skeletal
meshes.
Okay, so I'm going to get started with a

and this is going to start at the basics
so that everybody can kind of follow

So that's the end of my live demos for
now. There's a always a lot to cover
whenever we talk about mutable, but
these are videos just in case. But there
also are some limitations. So it can be
used in a lot of different places, but
it's not free. And I want to highlight
these because as you get into this and
you get into your games, you're going to
run into these issues. And I want to
kind of head those off ahead of time to
have you start thinking about how to
solve them. So the first one is at your
runtime consideration. It's not instant.
It runs asynchronously which is a good
thing because you're not blocking your
frame at the time in which you're
generating your assets. But it also
means that if you expect your asset to
be available to you when exactly when
you call create customizable instance,
it's not going to be ready. So make sure
that you like hide the mesh underneath
until it's ready to go. There is a
callback that you can hook into that
says, "Hey, I'm done." and then you can
show the mesh. It's very memory
demanding. So if you are a memory
constrained project for mobile or
anything like that, uh you can if you're
using it at runtime, it's going to use
up some memory because it generates all
these assets at runtime into memory and
you're going to want to think about how
much uh data you're using. Because we're
combining meshes and textures, we are
creating more memory efficient objects,
but it's going to use it. So keep that
in mind. And just like I showed with the
skeleton chain setup, it is skeleton
chain dependent. But I want to highlight
the example of like a backpack. So you
have your uh body skeleton and then you
have your backpack. What you want to do
for attaching a backpack and combining

root to the pelvis to the spine 1 2 3 4
5 and then hook into your backpack to
kind of hook those things together, but
it will still animate from there.
Another consideration is your connecting
systems. So, mutable is not a UX or UI

use UX systems inside of it. So, I show

There's a UI metadata section. So if you

you get the customizable objects from

a life service game and you have
services connections, you want to be

The other consideration is performance.
So even though mutable's goal is to
create more efficient and optimized
meshes, you're still creating skeletal
mesh components and you can get more
characters in the in the world, but
skeletal meshes on their own are
expensive. So keep that in mind when
you're generating large crowds that
you're still going to be paying the
cost, especially in memory for all those
different versions of the character.
Another thing to consider is large
customization systems. So longer compile
times if you have giant customizable
graphs and child objects. There's not a

working on something and I'll talk about

cost for generation time for textures in

analysing textures, just keep that in

thing that we want to drive is datal
driven customization. So all the things
